title: 112_hr3582
content: The "Pro-Growth Budgeting Act of 2012" is a new section added to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974, requiring macroeconomic impact analyses of major legislation. The Congressional Budget Office must provide a macroeconomic impact analysis for major bills or resolutions, based on projections for ten fiscal-year periods, as part of the "Pro-Growth Budgeting Act of 2012." The analysis prepared under subsection (a) shall describe the potential economic impact of major bills or resolutions on key economic variables, including GDP, business investment, employment, interest rates, and fiscal effects such as revenue changes. It should use various economic models to reflect possible outcomes and specify models, data sources, and transformations used. The macroeconomic impact analysis for major bills or resolutions includes estimates of economic changes like output, employment, interest rates, and tax revenues. It also considers revenue feedback and critical assumptions underlying the estimates. The text chunk discusses the definitions of terms related to budgetary effects and revenue feedback in major bills or resolutions. It also includes a conforming amendment to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. Sec. 407. Macroeconomic impact analysis of major legislation. Section 202(e) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to require the Director to submit supplemental projections to the Committees on the Budget of the House of Representatives and the Senate. These projections assume the extension of current tax policy for the upcoming fiscal year and the following 10 fiscal years. The Director is required to submit projections to the Budget Committees, including the effects of extending certain tax acts and the alternative minimum tax. The Director must provide annual long-term budget projections to the Budget Committees, including the effects of extending estate, gift, and generation-skipping transfer tax provisions. The House of Representatives passed the bill on February 2, 2012.
